frameDefinitions: An Agent or Cause makes a New_member part of  Group.

The Attaching frame covers two situations: a scene in which somebody causes one thing to be physically connected to something else; or a scene in which somebody causes two things to be connected to each other.
This frame is only for words that are used as the Titles of individuals.
In this frame a Profiled_item is higher that its Standard_item on a scale with respect to some Attribute.
The Self_mover, a living being, moves under its own direction along a Path.
frameExamples: I <t>added</t> a new rock to my collection.
The robber <t>tied</t> Harry to the chair.
He saluted <t>General</t> Fightmeister walking into the room.
Notices for the Shield Theater's production of Macbeth <t>surpassed</t> all previous reviews .
She <t>walked</t> along the road for a while.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Agent</fen> is a volitional animate being who causes the <fen>New_member</fen> to become part of the <fen>Group</fen>.
Something that is already a member of the <fen>Group</fen> and represents the <fen>Group</fen> as a whole.
An item that becomes a part of the <fen>Group</fen>.

The <fen>Group</fen> is anything that can be conceptualized as a complex collection of parts or ingredients, including through metonymy like containers or locations, which <fen>New_member</fen>s can join.
An animate or inanimate entity, a force, or event that is responsible for causing a <fen>New_member</fen> to enter a <fen>Group</fen>.
This role identifies when the inclusion of the <fen>New_member</fen> to the <fen>Group</fen> occurs.
The location in which a <fen>New_member</fen> is entered into a pre-existing <fen>Group</fen>.

The <fen>Agent</fen> manipulates an object. <fen>Agent</fen> typically refers to animate beings, but is also extended to mechanical and other inanimate objects.  It is most frequently expressed as the external argument of verbs.
This role identifies the <fen>Item</fen> that the <fen>Agent</fen> attaches to the <fen>Goal</fen>.
<fen>Goal</fen> identifies the location to which an <fen>Item</fen> is attached.
The <fen>Connector</fen> forms the bond that maintains the <fen>Item</fen> or <fen>Items</fen> in a fixed position; it is usually expressed in a <ment>with</ment>-PP.
This role identifies the plural <fen>Items</fen> that are tied together, resulting in their mutual attachment.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Agent</fen> intentionally affects the <fen>Item</fen> or <fen>Items</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the <fen>Agent</fen> intentionally affects an <fen>Item</fen> or <fen>Items</fen>.
The name of the person referred to by a <fen>Title</fen>.
How a person is referred to within an Institution, often denoting their rank or status. Title is always marked on the target.
The role <fen>Standard_item</fen> denotes the entities that are exceeded by the <fen>Item</fen> with regard to the <fen>Attribute</fen>.
The <fen>Profiled_item</fen> is the entity that is located closest to the end of the scale evoked by some <fen>Attribute</fen>.
The <fen>Attribute</fen> is a property that evokes a scale along which the <fen>Item</fen> is located closer to one extreme in  comparison to the <fen>Standard_item</fen>.
The <fen>Standard_attribute</fen> is used when the standard is a specific value on  a scale.
The <fen>Profiled_attribute</fen> is a particular value on a scale which is being compared to an <fen>Attribute</fen> or <fen>Standard_item</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Item</fen> is higher on the scale than the <fen>Standard</fen>.
<fen>Self_mover</fen> is the living being which moves under its own power. Normally it is expressed as an external argument.

<fen>Source</fen> is used for any expression which implies a definite starting-point of motion.
In prepositional phrases, the prepositional object expresses the starting point of motion.  With particles, the starting point of motion is understood from context.
<fen>Path</fen> is used for any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a <fen>Source</fen> nor a <fen>Goal</fen>.  This includes 'middle of path'' expressions.
<fen>Goal</fen> is used for any expression which tells where the <fen>Self_mover</fen> ends up as a result of the motion.

<fen>Area</fen> is used for expressions which describe a general area in which motion takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular and not to consist of a single linear path.  Note that this role should not be used for cases when the same phrase could be used with the same meaning with a non-motion target, since these should be annotated with the <fen>Place</fen> FE.
The direction that the <fen>Self_mover</fen> heads in during the motion.
The time when the motion occurs.

The <fen>Place</fen> is the location within which a defined motion takes place.  Any specified or implied  <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen> should designate a location contained with the <fen>Place</fen>.  This role can be differentiated from <fen>Area</fen> by the fact that the annotated phrase can be used in the same meaning with non-motion targets.
listRoleExamples: <fex>Matt</fex> seems to add new work to his flickr most days.
The companyincludes philanthropic endeavors in their accomplishments
<fex>The calls of crows</fex> added an eerie aspect to the atmosphere of our date.
<fex>The robber</fex> tied Harry to the chair.
The robber tied <fex>Harry</fex> to the chair.
The robber tied Harry <fex>to the chair</fex>.
The robber tied Harry to the chair  <fex>with a rope</fex>.
The robber tied <fex>Harry's ankles</fex> together.
The robber tied Harry to the chair <fex>at midnight</fex>.
The robber tied Harry to the chair <fex>in the basement</fex>.
Reverend <fex>Roberts</fex> wears wrinkled robes.
<fex><t>Judge</t></fex> Judy has made her decision.
In her time, she outstripped <fex>most politician in the country</fex>.
<fex>The buildings</fex> were outstripped in beauty and grace many years ago.
We  surpassed <fex>our father's skills</fex> .
<fex>Fred</fex> crawled the narrow passage.
The cat ran <fex>out of the house</fex>.
The scouts hiked <fex>through the desert</fex>.
The children skipped <fex>into the park</fex>.
The mouse scurried <fex>about</fex>.
You should walk <fex>south</fex> about a block .
The hitchhikers walked <fex>in the middle of the road</fex>.
